Jan 29

Time for the Orlando Magic to Blow It Up

Bad decisions have left the Orlando Magic in utter disaster. Is it time to take a step back so they can make a real move forward?

Acceptance can be tough. Hard decisions are something that do not come easily, but for the Orlando Magic it’s the path they are heading down. Unfortunately, sometimes the hardest thing and the right thing are the same.

It’s rebuilding time again in Orlando, and it’s going to take a full to-the-floor tear-down if they are going to do it properly this time around.

It all started with such hope. The Magic had around two max slots (close to $45 million) in created cap space, despite the horrific Tobias Harris trade forced through by former disgruntled coach Scott Skiles, who would later quit the team.

Frank Vogel arrived in May, with plenty of optimism in tow. The successful stint Vogel enjoyed in Indiana created a sense of belief for the Magic, and a team starved of playoff appearances since 2011–12 were starting to believe again.

Then the offseason happened. Victor Oladipo, Ersan Ilyasova & the first round draft pick (Domantas Sabonis) were gone first, shipped out on draft night for Serge Ibaka. Ibaka was of course the rim protector and athletic 3-and-D big that is so rare in the NBA. It was a risk, but one the Magic were willing to take? In a vacuum, it could be a win-win trade.

That was until the Magic hit free agency, and where the rest of the NBA zigged, Orlando seemingly zagged. Richard DeVos’ urgent desire for the franchise to be successful before he passes (he’s 90) meant that the team would try to accelerate the rebuilding process. As it’s known now, it was a disaster.

A four-year deal was handed out to Bismack Biyombo worth $72 million, when the team could have kept Dewayne Dedmon for a fraction of the cost. In a bizarre move, $15 million was given to journeyman Jeff Green, with an already loaded front court assembled making the move all the more confusing.

D.J. Augustin received four-years and $29 million, and a recent injury to the guard has only compounded the fact he’s struggled in Orlando through the first year of the deal. The best deal was certainly Evan Fournier, who inked a five-year, $85 million deal. Though his shooting percentages haven’t quite matched last years, the team having a dire lack of shooting hasn’t helped.

So now, languishing in the mire of the Eastern Conference doldrums and Vogel scrambling with some of the worst lineup combinations and rotations in the league at present, the Magic face a dilemma; stick with it or change course? Rob Hennigan’s job security is shaky at best, and he’s likely to lose his job either way with someone almost certain to be made the public face of blame.

Either way, the Magic need to tear it down. They might just need to swallow their own ego and pride to do so.

The first step is admitting that it simply isn’t working. The Magic defend in spurts (22nd overall) and possess the second-worst offense in the entire league. They don’t do anything particularly well, and they are an awful shooting team.

For all of their loaded front court, they are still a bottom ten rebounding team at 24th overall. Per NBA.com data, they’re 28th in free throw rate, 28th in true shooting percentage and on the other end they leak points in the paint for fun (25th overall). Their inability to excel at anything means their already existent weaknesses are only exacerbated.

Orlando’s roster is a mess to say the least, and they have to look ahead the offseason and the NBA draft to decide whether the work starts now. It needs to, and that means making moves before the trade deadline on February 23rd.

Serge Ibaka is an obvious candidate to be shipped out, and if the Magic do choose this direction he almost certainly should go. It’s no knock on Ibaka, who has been quite good since his arrival. He’s scoring at a career best rate per 36 minutes and is averaging 15 points per game whilst his true shooting percentage is it’s best in three years at .566 (.001 below his career average).

Unfortunately, Ibaka does not fit the Magic timeline and he can help another better off team right now. So why not the Toronto Raptors? Can Hennigan call Masai Ujiri and see if they can do a deal? It would certainly require a third team to make the salary math work, but Ibaka is a great fit on a team requiring a four who can also be a perfect small-ball five.

Enes Kanter’s Injury Hurts In More Ways Than One For The Thunder
Who’d of thought hitting a chair on the bench could potentially be so catastrophic? For Oklahoma City, it certainly…16winsaring.com

The deciding element of any Ibaka trade will be both what the opposing franchise will be willing to offer that makes sense for Orlando and whether that team believes it can retain the big man this summer with him hitting free agency. Could a couple of wings from Washington (such as Markieff Morris and Kelly Oubre Jr) and pick swaps reunite Ibaka with long time coach Scotty Brooks?

Could Charlotte try to revitalize their flailing season with Ibaka for Jeremy Lamb and a first round pick? It’s a tricky move and also requires a third team to make the deal work (Hornets would need to shed salary), but the Hornets have an ambitious management and ownership group and a core that needs to be capitalized on sooner rather than later. It’s worth asking the question.

The Houston Rockets are always an interested team at the deadline, and Daryl Morey has the magic touch to make those kinds of deals work. Ibaka also fits the mould for a Mike D’Antoni sort of stretch player who fits into a variance of lineups. The Portland Trail Blazers are another team who need all the help they can get defensively, and Ibaka isn’t what he was at that end but he’s a heap better than what the Blazers possess currently.

It’ll be tough, but there will be takers at the deadline for a player of Ibaka’s skill set and quality. What his return will be however, remains to be seen.

As for the rest of the roster, ideally the Magic need to pick who they will roll with for the rest of the season and beyond. Can they guarantee heavy minutes for the likes of Aaron Gordon and Mario Hezonja the rest of the season? With the former just needing minutes and the latter an unknown quality the Magic need to decide that for themselves.

How Good Can Aaron Gordon Be?
Orlando’s athletic forward is coming along nicely, and may have a comparable ceiling as a fellow 2014 draftee16winsaring.com

Nikola Vucevic has long been linked to trades out of Orlando, but like players of his ilk trade value is not easy to accumulate. Big men who are offensive weapons that also struggle defensively are not heavily desired on the trade market, and that might mean the Magic are better served keeping Vucevic in an Enes Kanter type of role. He’s on a very reasonable contract, earning around $25 million total over the next two seasons.

Jeff Green should be moved unless the Magic can’t find a way to complete the annual trade deadline tradition of trading Green for a first round pick for unbeknownst reasons. Fournier’s contract means they can afford to be patient with offers for his services, and he’s only 24.

Elfrid Payton is a curious case for the Magic. A poor shooter but potentially good floor general, Payton’s shooting issues are made worse by the fact the rest of the roster cannot alleviate them. Like Gordon, he has a year remaining beyond this season on his rookie deal and can be extended this summer. He’s likely not to be (Gordon is a much more difficult question), but Payton has flourished at times off the bench this season.

It granted his return to the starting lineup recently, and since then he has posted 15.7 points, 4.4 rebounds, 6.2 assists and 1.3 steals in 12 games. He’s shot 48 percent from the field and 42 percent from the perimeter on selective opportunities. It’s a small sample size, but Payton needs to start developing consistency if he wants a payday in 2018.

Optimal role placement and constant development are crucial for young players, and for guys that stay on the roster that has to be the focus for Vogel and the Magic. It may not be what he envisioned when he took the Orlando job, but that’s what it has become for him.

If ownership allows, Hennigan needs to begin another unfortunate rebuild, starting before the deadline shuts. Develop a new plan that the whole franchise aligns with, and see it out. Other organizations in Philadelphia, Los Angeles and Milwaukee are feeling the benefits of patience and belief in their direction.

Ask Chicago, New York, New Orleans, Sacramento and others how trying to accelerating the rebuild too quickly goes, it’s more often than not detrimental and can set back a tough process even further.

This in part, is why the Magic should be looking ahead to the NBA Draft in anticipation of landing the long awaited player they can pair with Aaron Gordon and build around. Gordon has shown flashes of being a franchise cornerstone, and in a floor general heavy draft the Magic need to find their way into landing one of those highly touted prospects. They are already in contention for this season’s “Tankathon”, after all:

With Phoenix improving, Dallas always trying to be competitive and Erik Spoelstra coaching the Miami Heat to 7 straight wins, Orlando can improve their chances at moving up the order and having their pick of the bunch. Where they end up because of the lottery remains to be seen, but at this point in their journey it can’t hurt to improve their chances.

Markelle Fultz is the dreamboat of this draft class at present and naturally is the best fit for the Magic. He can score, is an excellent outside shooter (44 percent from deep this season), can set up his teammates and is a bonafide leader.

Dennis Smith Jr is another great fit because of his ability to light it up and create shots for himself and his teammates, but is a score-first guy and that’s the type of player the Magic need more of. Lonzo Ball and De’Aaron Fox aren’t ideal fits to Orlando’s needs, which is in part why the Magic may want to help themselves have a wider selection of prospects.

Josh Jackson and Jayson Tatum are wing talents if the Magic don’t believe a Point Guard is their route, so they have other positional options at the top of the board.

It takes a man and in this case a strong organization courage to admit mistakes to move on from them as lessons learned. It’s time that took place in Orlando, or the drought of five years without postseason basketball will only become longer and more painful.

All statistics were from Basketball-Reference.com unless otherwise stated.
